10/14/15 07:06 AM EDT
BIDEN WAITED TOO LONG: ‘Dems seemed happy with their two options’ – HILLARY LANDSLIDE 

10/14/15 07:02 AM EDT
HRC plans Morristown fundraiser
We're working on more stories right now

                                            By 
                                                    POLITICO Magazine


                                            By 
                                                    Jeff Greenfield


                                            By 
                                                    Matt Latimer


                                            By 
                                                    POLITICO Magazine


2016

                        Time is ticking, and the vice president and the people looking at the race with him know it.

            By 
Edward-Isaac Dovere

10/14/15 05:04 AM EDT

                    Updated 10/14/15 01:08 PM EDT
“But what would the guy at the bubble-wrapped sixth podium have said?” is not a question that came up at the first Democratic debate. 
Hillary Clinton left as little room as she could for people to ask it. Over the course of two full hours of debate, no one even mentioned Joe Biden’s name. 
Story Continued Below
“This debate was about the five people on this stage,” said Clinton strategist Joel Benenson in the spin room after the debate, gingerly not engaging. “Vice President Biden has a very personal decision to make.”
Biden and his advisers knew that waiting until October to make a decision was a gamble: Would Clinton’s late-summer tailspin continue? Would she fumble and stumble through the first debate? And most importantly, would the primary race take off without him? 
Now, Biden's orbit has put out word that he’s going to take another week to make a decision — right up against Clinton’s appearance before the Select Committee on Benghazi that once seemed like it could become an embarrassing inquisition, but that she's now already framing a tedious partisan fishing expedition. 
While Biden may have seen four Clinton opponents without his debating chops struggle to distinguish themselves next to her on Tuesday night, he also saw that he was not, at least to the people on stage, the looming presence that some thought he’d be. Neither was she the wounded shark that Biden backers hoped might leave Democrats crying out for a savior. 



            By 
Daniel Strauss

Clinton’s challengers also denied Biden an opening as a “unifier” by opting not to attack her much, or with much fire. On the contrary, their near defense of Clinton at points only accentuated how much Biden would have to come in swinging hard to distinguish himself, which is never the kind of race he’ has liked to run and not one that he’s eager to run now. 
Not even reporters were pushing Clinton aides much about Biden in the spin room afterward. And her team demurred whenever the question did come up. 
But it’s not like he was so far from their minds—arriving in Las Vegas on Monday evening, Clinton made her first stop at a rally with the Culinary Workers Union, which Biden loyalists would hope to lean on in the Nevada primary if he got in (to the point that the vice president held a long meeting with one of the union’s top officers while in Los Angeles last month).
Time is ticking, and the vice president and the people looking at the race with him know it. Forget about rushing to put together tens of millions of dollars—they don’t yet have a bank account. Georgia and Michigan filing deadlines are coming up quickly, with others right behind, and they haven’t gotten past the preliminary conversations with most of the handful of people they’ve talked to about staffing a potential campaign. 
Instead of that James Bond-style surprise arrival in Vegas that political reporters spent two weeks obsessing over, Biden, according to his office, watched from the Naval Observatory. And what of that guess by some Democratic odds-makers that Biden would announce his candidacy the day after the debate? Turns out, according to his schedule, he’ll be spending Wednesday speaking at an infrastructure roundtable at the White House, having his weekly lunch with Obama and then sitting in on an Oval Office meeting with Secretary of State John Kerry. 



            By 
Nick Gass

And in a move that would thrill no campaign consultant, especially with a limited timeframe, his office put out word ahead of the debate that he’ll spend next Wednesday as part of a daylong forum in Washington joining Jimmy Carter to honor Walter Mondale. 
All this as Biden’s hard-earned brand of authenticity and party loyalty is weighed against the theory that he’s just sitting back, waiting to see if Clinton falters.
“I wouldn’t think that would be the criteria upon which he’d decide whether to run or not, but at this point he needs to make up his mind,” Clinton campaign Chairman John Podesta told Yahoo News in Las Vegas ahead of the debate.
“People’s patience are being tested here,” said former Obama adviser David Axelrod, who’s spoken about the possibility of running with Biden, on CNN ahead of the debate. 
Clinton closed what could have been multiple paths for Biden. She wove close to the president repeatedly through the debate, minimizing her policy disagreements and all but claiming his endorsement the first time she brought up his name. 
“He valued my judgment,” she said, shutting down the complaints from Bernie Sanders and others for that same Iraq War vote Obama beat her up for throughout the 2008 campaign, before picking her to be his secretary of state. 
She went on over the course of the night to list areas where she and Obama were side-by-side: that decision to go after Osama bin Laden (which, should it ever come to a head-to-head, she can point out that Biden took the other side on), cornering the Chinese to begin caving in on climate change, Obama’s position on Libya, his being “a great moral leader” on issues of race relations and grappling with police violence, all the more he would have gotten done if not for the obstruction of the Republicans. 
She also directed comments directly at Biden’s potential coalition partners, giving special mention to helping two groups—African-Americans and the LGBT community—that would be core to his support base if he were to run.
“For me, this is about bringing our country together again,” Clinton said, denying Biden a chance to cast himself as the one who could overcome divisions in America. “And I will do everything I can to heal the divides: the divides economically, because there's too much inequality; the racial divides; the continuing discrimination against the LGBT community.”



            By 
Daniel Strauss

Clinton didn’t linger much on her opposition to the Keystone XL pipeline, her insistence that Obama could go further on immigration and gun control, or on the Trans-Pacific Partnership that she called the “gold standard” back when she was a member of the administration, but now says she's read enough—though the final text is still not public—to know she's against it. 
Biden would be running to build on the work of the Obama administration, a third term with a twist. But Clinton beat him to it. 
“There's a lot that I would like to do to build on the successes of President Obama,” Clinton said. ”But also, as I'm laying out, to go beyond.”
Gabriel Debenedetti contributed reporting from Las Vegas.
 © 2015 POLITICO LLC
description: Time is ticking, and the vice president and the people looking at the race with him know it.
title: Clinton’s boxing Biden out
